text: Two large wooden doors open into a BEAUTIFUL LIBRARY. Bou leather books sit in mahogany bookshelves. Vaulted ceilin and ornate furniture suggest this place was made very lon ago. The CAMERA slowly approaches a table where a FINELY CRAFT BOOK lies open. The page reads “Chapter One,” and a color illustration shows an Italian town in the hills. Suddenly we HEAR a little voice call us ...
Psst! Up here! We look up and see an adorable little bat, hanging upside down in the corner of the library. This is FLYER.

It’s me, Flyer. Unable to contain his excitement, Flyer swoops down and l beside the book. He gestures toward the open page. FLYER (cont'd) Here to read the most romantic love story the world has ever known? (Hopefully) Mind if I read with you? I love a love story. The CAMERA moves in closer to the page’s illustration. In second or two we are INSIDE THE PICTURE.
We approach A DELIGHTFUL LITTLE TOWN tucked into a small valley between picturesque mountains. A full moon hangs i the cloudless sky.

Besides ... this story took place in my hometown. Verona. As we swoop down closer, the town’s towers and spires ris meet us. We circle around THE CATHEDRAL and come in for a closer look. The bell in the tower is ringing. Hanging upside down in the window of the BELFRY is a younger vers of Flyer. FLYER (V.O) (cont'd) I used to hang out in the Belfry. He drops out of the window and flies with us down a COBBLESTONE LANE lined with homes as pretty as gingerbrea houses. Lights flicker in nearly every window.  FLYER (V.O.) (cont'd) I was just a young whipper-snapper at the time ... As we approach THE PIAZZA where townsfolk happily call ou farewells to one another, Flyer bumps into a sign hanging front of The Butcher’s Store and knocks himself silly. FLYER (V.O.) (cont'd) +-. working out the kinks in my radar ... A moment later Flyer has gotten himself going again and approaches A BEAUTIFUL VILLA. A GROUP OF BIRDS are sitting on the banister of the balco watching something below. Flyer lands between a couple of PRETTY WHITE DOVES and tries to put his wings around them FLYER (V.O.) (cont'd) «+. this was back in my unpopular days The Doves look at one another clearly frightened of Flyer FLYER (V.O.) (cont'd) .--- back when everyone thought we bats were scary! IN A FLASH the Doves dart to the other side of the balcon where they clearly feel a lot more comfortable. All the other birds turn their backs on Flyer and look down into street. Flyer has to flap up onto the roof of the balcony get a view of ... A young man looking up to the balcony longingly, where a young woman looks sadly toward the moon. These young love are of course ROMEO and JULIET.
But soft! What light through yonder window breaks? It is the east, and Juliet is the sun!
Wait a second ...
Oh Romeo, Romeo! Wherefore art thou Romeo?

Hey! "(Whistling loudly) Wait a second, I said! A GIGANTIC IMAGE OF THE OLDER FLYER steps into our view o the lovers and blocks it almost completely. FLYER (cont'd) Wrong-o! Cease it! Cut! The CAMERA moves back to reveal FLYER standing in front the open book in the library. The picture on the page is of Romeo and Juliet. Flyer takes a step or two away from the book much like a trial lawyer about to spring a surprise on a witness. Suddenly he turns back to the page and points to the pict accusingly ... FLYER (cont'd) That is not the most romantic love story the world’s ever known! (Mockingly) Oh no no no no no. Far from it! The picture on the page of the book becomes animated agai Flyer looks at the young lovers almost disdainfully. FLYER (cont'd) I mean, yes, if you’re going to be technical about it. The story you’re talking about is nice. It has its moments ... On the balcony Juliet looks deeply into Romeo’s eyes.
What’s in a name! That which we call a rose by any other name would smell as sweet.

‘Course, some of the dialogue’s a little much, if you ask me. Now, if you want to see the most romantic story ... you got to look ... (Pointing to the corner of the picture) -.. down here ... The CAMERA now begins to RE-ENTER the illustration where Flyer has gestured to. FLYER (V.O.) (cont'd) .+. where only I could see it, sitting up there on the roof. The CAMERA moves slowly down off the balcony, down the si of the building, past the swooning Romeo, across the stre and down an embankment. FLYER (V.O.) (cont'd) This story comes from an entirely different part of Verona ...

Our view continues moving down to beside the river, where handsome golden retriever puppy watches Romeo’s every ges with admiration. This is ROVER.  FLYER (V.O.) (cont'd) And involves different characters altogether. Two other puppies hang out nearby. BENNY, a goofy looking basset hound, chases his tail in circles, kicking up mud everywhere. MERCURY, a brown and black bulldog, exercises rigorously, further sculpting his already fine-tuned four legged physique. FLYER (V.O) (cont'd) Though these characters from time to time may seem a little familiar ... Rover sighs loudly, completely oblivious to his friends’ canine concerns.
Oh, I wish I was in love. Benny momentarily stops his twirling and looks at Rover.
Love? What do you want to be in love for, Rover? All that sniffing each other and stuff. Yeech!
But Benny, then you have somebody, and they have you.
You have more than that.
What do you mean?

Rover, just think about it, would you? Oh sure, it’s all fun in the beginning. Candlelight dinners at the cozy trash can behind the butchers’. Making puppy-dog eyes at one another. But then things change. One thing leads to another. Pretty soon you got a litter full of problems to worry about.
I suppose ... but still, I want to be in love ... Benny has resumed his tail-chasing routine. Mercury turns him clearly annoyed.
Benny, dog gone it! Don’t you know you’re never gonna catch your tail?

(Continuing to chase his tail) Yes, I am! Yes I am! I almost ... got it ... And he promptly chases his tail ... right into the river! second later he comes up for air, panicking ... BENNY (cont'd) I can’t swim! I can’t swim! Mercury, help me!
Just don’t panic!
What do I do?
Paddle!
How?

Dog paddle. Benny seems to get the hang of it. MERCURY (cont'd) That's it. A moment later Benny pulls himself ashore, completely drenched. MERCURY (cont'd) What did I tell you? But would you listen? No!
But I almost had it that time, I swear. Just as Benny shakes himself off we hear a DEEP AUTHORITA VOICE ...

And just what are you pups up to? The three young dogs turn and discover a pack of street-w dogs who peer down at them sternly. One of the older dogs clearly the leader. This is Rover's father, BIG DADDY MONGREL. Big Daddy is dripping wet and clearly unamused. The young dogs leap to attention guiltily.
(Stammering) N - nothing, Big Daddy. W - we’re j - just -
Doggin’ it! You boys are supposed to be off collecting scraps.
I tried to tell them, sir, but they wouldn't listen. Big Daddy Mongrel gives Rover a disapproving look. Rover lowers his eyes ashamed.

Come here, son. Big Daddy Mongrel puts a paw on Rover’s shoulder and look into his eyes. BIG DADDY MONGREL (cont’d) You’re almost a year old now. Don’t you think it’s about time you start acting like it?
I know, I know ...
Your mother and I got hopes for you. You think I got to be the top dog rolling around in the daisies? No. You got to work for it.
He says he wants to be in love, Big Daddy.
What? Is that true, Rover?
Well ... yes.
You spend too much time playing fetch with Romeo.
There’s nothing wrong with Romeo. He’s nice to me. He brings me biscuits and scratches behind my ears -
Well! If Romeo is so nice ... Big Daddy Mongrel stares at his son truly angry now.
++. Can you tell me why he’s falling in love ... Big Daddy Mongrel points dramatically up to Juliet.
+.. with a CAT OWNER! !
Juliet owns cats?
Where do you think the Cat-Pulet’s live, boy? Big Daddy Mongrel looks at Romeo disdainfully. BIG DADDY MONGREL (cont’d) That boy’s probably got cat hair all over him by now.
(Disillusioned) No!
So let me hear no more of Romeo or love. They are dangerous influences. Rover nods sadly. It is like he has lost a hero. BIG DADDY MONGREL (cont’d) Now get out there and get us some scraps!

Yes, Father. The three young dogs leave their elders with their tails between their legs. After a moment, Rover takes a last lo up to the balcony. ROVER (cont'd) I didn’t know Juliet owns cats. Our view now begins to focus on Juliet’s window.
Are you kidding? She’s got more cats than I got fleas.
Really?

Can you believe that? Actually liking cats?  INT. JULIET’S BEDROOM Inside Juliet’s window we see that the young lover sits o chair crying for Romeo. In her sadness, she reaches for a black and white, nearly full-grown kitten.
They say she even pets them... Juliet puts the kitten on her lap. MERCURY (0.S.) (cont’d) Sometimes they even sit on her lap!
It's so ... so... tragic. Juliet looks in the kitten’s eyes.

Oh Juliet, true friend Juliet, what dost thou think I should do? LADY AND LORD CAT-PULET, two immaculately groomed long-ha cats, sit on Juliet’s vanity table. They are the kitten’s parents. When Lady Cat-Pulet hears the girl call the kitt “Juliet,” she shakes her head.
I still can’t believe that girl named her pet after herself!
You have to remember, the child’s only fourteen.
I’m fourteen, too! You see me doing anything so foolish?
No dear ... The human Juliet (hereafter referred to as “Juliet the Gi sets the kitten Juliet (hereafter referred to as “Juliet” her lap. Then she takes a tissue and looks longingly out window.

(Sniffling) Dost thou think Romeo will be true? Below Juliet the Girl’s chair sits DOC, a persian cat wit furtive eyes and a manner of speaking very akin to Mae We When she and the other cats talk near people, they do so under their breaths, and it is very clear that humans are aware that the animals are talking.

Oh please ... Juliet the Girl lets her tissue drop to the ground. Doc picks it up and hands it to Lady and Lord Cat-Pulet on th vanity table. Lord Cat-Pulet is taking the tissues from D and writing on them with an eye-liner. Lady Cat-Pulet put paw-prints on them using ruby-red lipstick. DOC (cont'd) --- doesn’t she know men are dogs? TYGER, a ferocious striped cat with a menacing smile, sit Juliet the Girl’s bed. He practices hurling his claws int picture of a dog like humans throw darts at a dart board.
You give men a bad name, Doc. Only dogs are dogs.
Maybe baby, but every male of every species has a bit of canine in him. Even you, Tyger. Tyger swats a ball of yarn at Doc, but she dodges it easi

Stop it you two. We have work to do. LADY CAT-PULET (cont'd) Juliet, come on. These invitations for the animal ball have to go out tomorrow. Juliet whispers discreetly as Juliet the Girl continues t cry.
Mother, what am I supposed to do?
Act prissy. It’s every cat’s prerogative.
I can’t do that. Juliet needs me.
(Mocking) Needs you! Until she’s got a date.

That's not true! Juliet’s different ... Meanwhile, TYBALT, a dashing young human in his late teen has come into Juliet the Girl’s room. He picks Tyger up o the bed and throws him into the air! As Tyger screeches horribly and struggles to land on his feet, Tybalt laughs delightedly.  10.
Tybalt!
Oh come now dearest cousin, they’re only cats. Juliet the Girl sets Juliet down and crosses to Tyger.

They’re more than that. They’re my friends. She pats Tyger on the head. JULIET THE GIRL (cont’d) You all right, little one? Tyger purrs happily. Juliet turns proudly back to Doc, gesturing to Juliet the Girl.
You see how Juliet is different?
Well, thoust will never guess what I did find downstairs after the ball.
What?
Evidence that Montagues were there.
Montagues!
Yes, come this way and I will show you. Tybalt and Juliet the Girl leave. Tyger heads over to the ball of yarn.
Come on, help me roll this up.
No.
Why not?
I can’t stand yarn.
How can you be a cat and not like a ball of yarn?  11.
I don’t know. She leaps to the window sill and looks outside longingly.
I like the ball in the sky. What do you call that?
It’s the moon.
The moon. Oh I think it is so beautiful.
Beautiful? What’s so beautiful about the moon. Next you’ll be howling like a dog at it.
But I think it’s beautiful. I do. She looks at the globed lamp posts.

And the balls of light outside. And the balls that people throw to one another in the park. Sometimes I see balls bouncing down the street so fast. Not like balls of yarn that roll a couple feet and stop. But balls that go faster and faster. Sometimes I want to chase those balls. Right outside, into the big wide world. Lady and Lord Cat-Pulet look at one another concerned. Lo Cat-Pulet clears his throat and gives Doc a look that mea something like, “will you talk some sense into the girl?” Doc sets down her work and goes up to Juliet on the windo sill.
Juliet, you’re not feeling ... curious are you?
Yes, I am.
How many times do I have to tell you that curiosity kills -

But I don’t see why it has to. Don’t you ever wonder, Doc, what it must be like to live outside? MEANWHILE OUTSIDE ...  12. Rover, Benny and Mercury are looking for scraps. Mercury scans the contents of some trash cans they’ve just dumped over much as a construction foreman oversees a project.

Nothin’ here, come on. He immediately heads off toward the next alley. As soon a he’s out of sight, Benny jumps on top of one of the trash cans like a western log-roller. Rover takes one whiff of garbage and grimaces. A second later he glances up to a window. It is not Juliet’s window.
Benny?
(Trying to balance himself) Yeah?

Have you ever wondered what it must be like to live ... inside? The sound of the word “inside” literally sends Benny hurl He falls face first into a barrel. A moment later he reappears covered in goop.
Inside?
Yeah.
You think you’re some kind of poodle, or something?
No, no, I just wonder. Don’t you ever wonder? INSIDE ... Juliet looks out the window.

I imagine flowers and sunshine and leaping in the trees. There’d be wide open spaces and rivers and lakes and you could go swimming! Doc gives Juliet a look like she has gone completely off rocker. OUTSIDE ... Rover continues to peer into windows longingly.  13.

I imagine a fireplace and music and chewing a shoe. There’d be food served in bowls and I'd wear bells ... anda ribbon in my hair. Benny puts a paw on Rover’s forehead to make sure he does have a fever. INSIDE ... Juliet leads Doc into the kitchen, where we see pet dishe the floor. Tyger tails along behind, looking on suspiciously.
Don’t you ever get tired of warm milk and cold tuna and wearing these tight collars?
But they’re diamond studded. You know how I love studs.

Call me crazy, but in my dreams I see myself standing on a tall bridge, taking off this horrid collar and throwing it into the river! OUTSIDE ... Rover turns a corner and directs Benny’s attention to a g of sad and lonely dogs struggling to survive in the stree Mercury looks at his two friends with concern.
Don’t you ever get tired of dog catchers and cold nights and digging in the trash?
I love trash!
Call me crazy, but in my dreams I see myself settling down to sleep on a satin pillow beside my master’s bed. INSIDE ... Juliet leaps to the kitchen window and looks out.
That's what the outside would be, a place where I could be me, a place where I could be ...
What?  14.
Free. OUTSIDE ... Rover jumps a short hedge and peers in the front window o charming little home. Benny is right behind.
That's the kind of place that I crave, a place where you don’t even have to be brave, a place where for once I would be
What?
Safe.
A dreamy smile spreads across Benny’s face as he gets cau up in Rover's fantasy. INSIDE ... Doc has nearly the exact same look on her face, but Tyger SCREECHES and brings an end to that.
It’s not all fun and games out there, you know?
It isn’t?
There’s lots of stuff you have to do that isn’t fun.
Like what?
Well ... like scratching yourself for instance.
Scratching myself? But whatever for?
Because you’1ll have fleas!
Fleas! My goodness!
And what’s more ... Tyger whispers something in Juliet’s ear that surprises h  15.
Really?
Really!
But I don’t even know what a fire hydrant is! OUTSIDE ... Mercury SNARLS at Rover as well.
Don’t kid yourself, home sweet home ain’t all it’s cracked up to be.
It isn’t?
No.
Why not?
Well, because you have to keep yourself clean.
Clean? What’s that mean?
It means you have to lick yourself all the time.
Really?
And you even have to ... Mercury whispers in Rover’s ear. Rover turns to him startled.
In a box?
In_a_box! INSIDE ... Tyger and Doc lead Juliet back into the bedroom.  16.
So don’t get yourself all excited. It’s a jungle out there, kiddo. OUTSIDE ... Mercury and Benny lead Rover back to the trash cans.
So don’t go getting a bunch of ideas. It can be war in there, buster. INSIDE ... As Doc and Tyger go back to work on the invitations, Juli looks out the window again.
Still, sometimes I can’t help wonder ... OUTSIDE ... Rover looks up to a window again as Mercury and Benny go to scrounging.
Still, sometimes I can’t help wonder ...
Both Rover and Juliet look forlornly toward the different worlds they seek.
What it would be like ...
What it would be like ...
+.. to live outside.
+.. to live inside.

The colorful town square is teeming with SHOPPERS. Italia VENDORS peddle everything from fresh produce to fine clothing. The camera pans down through the crowd until we are almost ground-level in front of a WATCHMAKER’S KIOSK. Passing by are the legs and feet of busy shoppers. SUDDENLY, Rover’s head pops out from under the red curtai that encircles the kiosk. He anxiously looks around, maki sure not to be seen.  17.

(From behind the curtain) How’s it look, Rover? Rover looks directly across from the watchmaker’s kiosk a THE MEAT STAND. A FAT BUTCHER is in the process of cutting steaks and cho for his customers. Rover licks his lips ...
Like dinner! And then some! With that, a GIANT PAW pulls Rover behind the curtain.
Hiding behind the curtain are Benny and Mercury. Big Dadd Mongrel holds Rover by a tuft of hair.
This is a delicate operation, boys. One wrong move could land you in the pound.
(Cocky) Not to worry, Pops ... Big Daddy looks at him sternly.
(Gulping) --. I mean, Big Daddy. Big Daddy finally puts a relieved Rover down.
Benny, I need you to cause a distraction. Something wild.
(Still trying to catch his own tail) How do I do that, Big Daddy?
Trust me. Just be yourself. Mercury, you back up Rover while he’s nabbing the goods.
You can count on me, Big Daddy.
Good luck, boys. Make this old Mongrel proud. The three dogs head out. Big Daddy is clearly worried abo  18. his pups.
Rover and Mercury make their way towards the meat stand. Benny lags behind.

Something wild ... something wild ... Benny notices a JUGGLER performing for a group of childre The juggler has several red balls in the air. Behind him a vegetable stand. Benny spots a_pile of ripe tomatoes and suddenly has an i

While The Butcher is busy helping his customers, Rover an Mercury sneak up from behind. Benny positions himself in crowd. Rover waits, then gives Benny the signal. With that, Benn begins to BARK as loud as he can. The crowd of people tur to look. Amazingly, Benny climbs up on his hind legs and JUGGLES T TOMATOES WITH HIS FRONT PAWS. People ooh and aah. Even The Butcher watches in amazement. Meanwhile, Rover jumps onto the meat counter and begins pushing steaks and chops down to Mercury. Benny continues to juggle for the adoring crowd. In no ti at all he is up to twelve tomatoes! But when Benny goes f number thirteen, they all come tumbling down on his head. Benny is left covered in tomato juice. The crowd sighs and returns to shopping. It is then that Butcher finally notices what Rover is doing.

Hey, you stinky mongrel! Those are my steaks! The Butcher picks up his MEAT CLEVER, but just before he slice Rover in two ... BUTCHER (cont'd) Aaaaaaah!!!! Mercury BITES him on the leg, giving Rover the chance to escape.

Rover runs through the crowd. When he turns for a split second to see if he’s being chased, the terrified pup ...  19. SLAMS RIGHT INTO A PAIR OF LEGS. A bit dazed, Rover looks and finds ... .-. ROMEO staring right down at him.

Alas, ‘tis my favorite stray. Romeo scoops up Rover, who still has a steak hanging in h mouth. ROMEO (cont'd) Thou art a criminal in need of a place to hide. Come. We shall find you a fine wine to go with your meal.
Mercury and Benny, still covered in tomatoes, make their home.
You had to be a hot shot, didn’t you. Like a dog juggling twelve tomatoes wasn’t enough of a distraction. You just had to go for thirteen!
I like to challenge myself.
Believe me, Big Daddy is going to do more than that when he finds out we blew the caper.
Romeo, still holding Rover, looks through the many wines.

Wine seller, bring me your most prized vintage. Tonight is a special occasion. The Wine Seller bows and goes in back. Romeo leans down a whispers to Rover, unaware that the dog can understand ev word he says. ROMEO (cont'd) Can you keep a secret, my friend? I, a Montague, am to marry Juliet, a Capulet, in secret tonight at the old church. As if on cue, AN EXPENSIVE HORSE-DRAWN CARRIAGE appears i the piazza. Lord and Lady Capulet step out, followed by their evil nephew, Tybalt. Tybalt spots Romeo and throws him a nasty look.  20. ROMEO (cont'd) Perhaps our marriage can finally bring this feud between our families to an end. EXT. CAPULET’S CARRIAGE When The Capulets are well out of sight, the carriage’s b compartment pops open and out jumps Tyger. He makes sure that the coast is clear, then calls for his henchcats.
Shake! Speare! SHAKE and SPEARE, two Siamese cats who bear an amazing resemblance to The Bard, slowly climb out of the carriage
To be ...
Or not to be ...
Where are the party invitations? Shake and Speare look at one another and shrug.
Now that is the question. Frustrated, Tyger WHOOPS them both on the head. He then jumps back into the carriage, locates the invitations and throws them down.
Make sure every animal gets one. The henchcats scoop up the invitations and head off into piazza.
Friends...!
Romans...!
Country mice...!
Lend me your ears! Tyger shakes his head in embarrassment.

I gotta get me some new henchcats ... Just then, Tyger spots Rover in Romeo’s arms. The two mak eye contact. Tyger hisses and throws the nervous puppy a  21. look as nasty as Tybalt’s. He comes after Rover, ready to attack. EXT. WINE SELLER’S KIOSK As Tyger approaches, Rover jumps out of Romeo’s arms and makes a run for it.
Hey! Where’s thou going?
Rover runs through the piazza and winds up in a dark and scary alley. He comes to a dead end, and when he tries to turn around, Tyger suddenly JUMPS down right in front of
Don’t you know stray dogs aren’t allowed in the piazza?
Well, um...
All I'd have to do is get the dog catcher’s attention.
(Trying to be brave) Why don’t you leave me alone. I wasn’t bothering you.

You're a dog. Your mere existence bothers me. Tyger moves closer, menacingly. TYGER (cont'd) It's been a long time since I clawed anyone. Almost a week. Tyger raises his razor sharp claws above Rover's head.
Why don’t you pick on somebody your own size. Tyger turns to find Mercury and Benny.
Two against one. Not what you’d call a fair fight. Mercury pushes Benny to the side with Rover.
How’s that?  22.

That’s not fair either. For you, that is ... Tyger LUNGES at Mercury. The two animals literally fight like cats and dogs, rolling all the way back into the pia People run and scream to get out of the way. EXT. THE PRINCE’S ROYAL BOX From his seat high above the piazza, THE PRINCE notices t commotion. He signals for his PAGE.
What’s going on down there?
It looks like a cat and dog fighting, my liege.

Just what I need. More fighting! Noticing that The Prince is agitated, a SERVANT races to side and begins massaging his temples. THE PRINCE (cont’d) As if The Capulets and The Montagues weren’t enough of a headache. Send for my royal dog catcher to break it up.
Yes, my liege. (Shouting)

head_text.subj: SEND FOR THE ROYAL DOG CATCHER

text: The command is heard repeated by a series of pages until reaches ...
The cages are teeming with strays. THE ROYAL DOG CATCHER, tall and sinister-looking fellow dressed entirely in blac polishes his silver dog catcher’s net.
(Smiling) Party time.
Mercury and Tyger are still going at it, knocking over everything in their path. With all of his strength, Mercu pushes Tyger to the ground and raises his paw in the air.
Say nighty-night, Kitty.  23. A GALLOPING SOUND is suddenly heard. Rover turns and find the Dog Catcher racing toward him on his black horse.

Merc’, it’s the fuzz! Mercury looks up and sees the dog catcher’s net about to swoop down on Rover! He jumps off of Tyger and pushes his friend out of the way just in the nick of time. The three dogs make a run for it.
The puppies race to get out of the piazza. But The Dog Catcher is right on their tails, whipping his horse to ru faster.
He’s almost got us!
This way! Mercury leads the dogs through a narrow passage between t kiosks. But as Rover tries to escape, THE DOG CATCHER GRA

(ala The Wicked Witch) I’ve got you my pretty...! But The Dog Catcher’s wrong. Mercury and Benny, pulling Rover from the other side, save their friend. Rover’s tai slips right through The Dog Catcher’s hands. DOG CATCHER (cont'd)
He watches as the three dogs vanish into the streets. DOG CATCHER (cont’d) Next time your tail is mine.
The dogs stop to catch their breath.
That was too close for comfort.
You’re telling me! Thanks for saving my tail, guys.
Anytime. In the gutter, TWO RATS hold one of the Cat-Pulets’ party invitations.  24.
What are you going as?
I don’t know. I always wanted to be a hamster.
A hamster? That’s so obvious.
What are you rats talking about?
We just got invited to the social event of the season. Any animal who’s anyone will be there.
Hey, we’re animals. (Thinking) Aren’t we?

Lemme see that ... Mercury grabs the invitation. It reads, ‘LORD AND LADY CAT-PULET CORDIALLY INVITE YOU TO THEIR COSTUME BALL. PLEASE RSVP. P.S. NO DOGS ALLOWED!’ MERCURY (cont'd) Well if that don’t beat all. The furballs are having a ball. And we ain’t invited.
No big surprise, seeing how much they hate us.
Maybe so. But if this shindig is good enough for a bunch of rats ...
Hey!
--. well then it’s good enough for a bunch of dogs. And I think I know just how to get even with Tyger in the process. You boys game?
Absolutely!

Just as long as I don’t have to juggle.  25. THE NIGHT OF THE CAT-PULET’S PARTY - MONTAGE Animals throughout Verona don various costumes. EXT. VERONA’S ZOO - MONTAGE The monkeys swipe the sleeping zookeeper’s keys and let t other exotic animals out of their cages.

A virtual menagerie makes its way through the city toward Cat-Pulet’s villa. Some of the animals are easy to recogn under their costumes (the elephant dressed as a kangaroo, example), while others are completely disguised.
Lord and Lady Cat-Pulet greet their guests as they arrive the front gates. When the elephant shows up, they have hi go around back.
An oriental-looking building. A statue of a red dragon ha over its entrance.

Dressed as three skunks, Rover, Mercury, and Benny roll fireworks out of their boxes and into a brown sack. But when Benny goes to scratch himself, one of the unlit fireworks flies into the air. Fortunately, Rover catches just in time.
Careful, Benny!
Sorry. But this costume itches. (Sniffing himself) And it smells bad too.
You're supposed to smell bad. You’re a
Oh yeah ...
(Holding up one of the bottle rockets) Mercury, are you sure this plan is going to work?

Trust me. By the time we’re through, those cats won’t know what hit ‘em.  26. INT. JULIET’S BEDROOM Doc, dressed as a sexy cheetah, and Juliet, dressed as a polar bear cub, put some last minute touches on their costumes.
How do I look?
Terrific. You’re going to knock ‘em dead tonight, Doc.
Well, the cheetah is the fastest cat on earth ...

Zip me up. Doc helps Juliet into her costume. It is now impossible t tell that she is a cat. EXT. THE CAT-PULETS’ VILLA The dogs, hidden entirely under their skunk costumes, fol Mercury across the street to the party. The Cat-Pulets, unaware of who they are, greet them at the door.
My, what clever costumes.
I’m smelly and I’m darn proud of it! Mercury suddenly notices that Benny’s tail is beginning t stick out. He rushes to get Benny passed The Cat-Pulets.
Come on, big mouth.

The entire place is wall to wall with animals. An orchest made up of penguins plays classical music. Flyer, dressed a peacock, dances in mid-air with an eagle. When the dogs enter, they make a bee-line for the buffet.
Get a load of this spread!
Eat up, boys. In a few minutes, this party’s going to be history.  27. MEANWHILE ... Doc is surrounded by various animals who want to dance wi her.

Please don’t fight. I’m only one kitty! Juliet smiles at her friend’s good fortune. But her smile suddenly turns into a frown when she sees her parents and VIENNA, a snobby Viennese bachelor cat, approaching.
Juliet, you remember Vienna, don’t you?
(Grimacing) Of course. Vienna, dressed as a unicorn, smiles lasciviously.
Juliet, how purr-fect you look tonight! Vienna bends down to kiss Juliet’s paw but pokes her with horn. Juliet screams.
I’m soooo sorry! I’m not used to being mythological. Vienna laughs at his own lame joke. Juliet’s had just abo enough of this drip.
Will you excuse me? I think I see a monkey I know by the buffet.
The orchestra finishes its song. The animals applaud.
The boys and I are going to take five for a couple of ice cubes. Flyer’s dance partner smiles and gives him a peck on the cheek as she flies off. He sighs and looks at his peacock feathers.
This is the one night each year when nobody's afraid of me. (Looking over at his dance partner) I sure wouldn’t mind another.

The dogs are seriously digging in. But as Rover reaches across the table, his black, skunk paw accidentally bumps into a white, furry one. He looks up and finds none other than Juliet herself. Their eyes meet and it is LOVE AT FIRST SIGHT!
Wow ...
You have the most amazing eyes.
So do you.
You can tell a lot about someone from their eyes.
Oh yeah? What do mine say?
That you’re honest ...
Uh .. well ... usually.

And that you’re looking for something. Or maybe, someone. Rover and Juliet stare at one another, transfixed. Just then, the orchestra starts up again. JULIET (cont'd) Would you like to dance ...? Rover is tempted, then looks over at Mercury and Benny and remembers why he is here.
Oh I don’t know ...

Come on. It’s easy. And besides, when’s the next time you’re going to see a polar bear and a skunk dancing together? Rover smiles, then gets pulled onto the dance floor by Juliet. A formal, Renaissance-like dance begins. Rover looks around awkwardly, uncertain what to do. Trying to mimic what the others are doing, Rover steps right on Juliet’s foot! It’s all Juliet can do to keep from crying out.
I’m sorry!  29.

It’s all right ... Don’t worry about the others. She turns his face to hers. JULIET (cont'd) Look at me. Looking into those eyes, a kind of miracle comes over Rov He boldly twirls Juliet with precision. JULIET (cont'd) That’s it! In no time, Rover and Juliet are dazzling everyone at the party with their dancing prowess. The Cat-Pulets dancing nearby can’t even begin to keep up with them. As the song ends, the spectators applaud for Rover and Juliet. Rover leads her off the dance floor away from the other Cat-Pulets. JULIET (cont'd) I'd say you’re a natural.
I'd say you’re a great teacher.
Not that good.
In your arms, anything seems possible. Rover looks at Juliet strangely.
Or should I say, “in your paws”, or “in your wings”? She looks back at him furtively.
Are you trying to figure out what I am?
Maybe so.
That's strictly against the rules, you know.
I like breaking rules.
Well, these aren’t wings. I’m no chicken, that’s for sure.
Are you a lamb?
No.
A rabbit?
Sorry.
A goat?
(Coyly) Uh-huh.
Oh come on! I just have to know.
Just have to, huh? What do you say ... (An idea comes over her) .-. I show you instead?
Are you just going to take off your mask?
I will if you will. Rover gulps and looks around fearfully.
Here?
Why not?
How about we go to the garden instead? I’m kinda shy.
All right, then. 1I/’11 meet you there in five minutes. Juliet hurries off. Rover almost swoons.
I’m in love! Mercury appears in a huff.
What gives, Rover? We’re here to do some damage, not win a dance contest.  31. Rover sees Juliet walk outside.
I know, I know ... but I think the polar bear is on to us. I’m just trying to keep her ... distracted.
Well hurry it up. Benny’s setting up the pyrotechnics even as we speak.
Under the starry night, Juliet awaits her true love. Rove sneaks up from behind and places his paws over her eyes.
Guess who?
The animal of my dreams?
Close enough. Rover walks around in front of Juliet.
Ready ... ? Rover looks around one last time to make sure that the co is clear.
Let’s do it.
On the count of three. One ...
Two ...
Three! Rover and Juliet lift their masks. Both are shocked.
What are you doing at my family’s party? You must know we, I mean they, hate dogs.
You mean you don’t hate dogs too?
I can’t hate someone I don’t even know. That would be silly.
I guess you’re right.
So what are we going to do? I mean it seemed like we were sort of becoming, I don’t know ... friends.
Yeah, it sure seemed that way. But I just don’t think the world’s ready for a cat and a dog being ... friends.
Yeah, I guess not. Both are terribly saddened by this realization.
Well, see ya... Rover puts on his mask and starts back inside.
Hey ... I don’t even know your name.
It’s Rover.
I’m Juliet.
(Gesturing to the balcony) You mean like the girl ...?
That's right.
Rover and Juliet. I like that.
I like that too.
Though it does sound vaguely familiar .. Juliet smiles, slightly.  33. ROVER (cont'd) Well ... ‘Night, Juliet.
Good night, Rover. Rover leaves. A single tear drop falls from Juliet’s eye.
Rover meets up with Mercury and Benny.
Where have you been?! The fireworks are just about to begin.
You know, Merc’, I don’t think this is such a good idea after all. I mean, maybe The Cat-Pulets aren’t so bad ...

Are you nuts? We’re finally going to give these stuck up house-fluffers what they deserve. Mercury jumps onto a chair. MERCURY (cont'd) Listen up, animals of Verona! It’s time for tonight’s entertainment, courtesy of the three muske-skunks. Hit it, Benny! Benny pushes down on a GIANT BOMB PLUNGER, setting off th fireworks and bottle rockets. It is chaos as the animals panic and try to flee. In the confusion, Rover finds Juli He pulls off his mask.
Juliet, I’m sorry. I tried to stop them. I really did.
I believe you, Rover. But you better leave before my family gets their hands on you. Rover and Juliet desperately want to kiss before parting, can’t. As Rover flees the mayhem, Tyger spots him.
I knew it! The Mongrels! As Tyger starts to go after Rover, Lord Cat-pulet stops h  34.
Wait. Now’s not the time for revenge. Help calm our guests. You’ll get that little doggie soon enough.
Flyer, still in his peacock uniform, is struggling to fly home with all his long tail feathers.

Would you look at this? How you supposed to fly with tail feathers like this? When one of his elongated wings hits a tree branch, Flyer plummets to the earth. FLYER (cont'd) And he falls with a tremendous splash in a bird bath. He ends up completely drenched. FLYER (cont'd) It's hard being beautiful. Dragging himself out of the bird bath, Flyer finds he has peacock feathers sticking out in every direction. Starting to pluck them out left and right, he notices Rov moping in the shadows by the cathedral. FLYER (cont'd) Hey there, Rover. What’s the matter?
Oh, Flyer, it’s terrible!
What?
I’m in love! At least I think I’m in love.
But Rover that’s wonderful! You've wanted to be in love forever!
I know, I know, but ...
But what?
-.. it’s with a ... Cat-Pulet!  35.
You mean Juliet?
Yes!
(Confused) And that’s a problem?
Flyer! She’s a cat!
So?
And I’m a dog! Flyer gives Rover a perplexed look. ROVER (cont'd) Can’t you see? I don’t think the world is ready for a dog-cat relationship.
The world? Rover, since when have you ever worried about what the world thinks, huh? Flyer looks at Rover, but the dog lowers his eyes. FLYER (cont'd) This is more about what you think, isn’t it?
I’m just so confused. I don’t know if I should ... I don’t even know if I could -+- Do you know any dog who would ...?
Love a cat?
Yeah. Rover shakes his head and walks away from Flyer dejected.
Rover ...
What? Flyer finally has his entire costume off and flies over a lands in front Rover.  36.
Rover!
What?
Let me ask you something. When you look at me, what do you see?
What do you mean, what do I see? I see you. Flyer.
And do you see that I’m a bat?
Of course, I see that you’re a bat.
So then why aren’t you ... Flyer bares his pathetically short fangs, not looking eve remotely frightening ...
-.. afraid of me, huh?
Why would I ever be afraid of you?
Because a lot of creatures think I’m scary.
They do?
Oh yeah, they don’t even like me being around. Flyer takes a hop toward a couple of squirrels, who immediately scram in opposite directions.
See what I mean? Without that peacock costume I would never have gotten in to the animal ball tonight.
But why are they afraid of you?
I don’t know. Maybe ... Flyer flies under a dark awning and hangs upside down.  37.
... it’s because we like hanging upside down in the dark.
What’s scary about that?
Beats me. Flyer comes back down to Rover now.
Maybe they think we carry germs or something, or we’re sneaky because we fly so quiet. Did you know that some creatures even think we’re evil?
Evil?

Oh yeah. Four hundred years from now they’re going to be making all these movies about bats who turn into vampires and bite people’s necks and say ... Flyer does his best Bela Lugosi. FLYER (cont'd) “I vant to suck your blood.”

But that’s ridiculous! You don’t want to suck anybody’s blood. You’re not a vampire! And you don’t carry germs either. You’re the cleanest, most honest creature in Verona. How could anybody think that you are scary?
I don’t know, but somehow they do.
Well, that’s crazy! Flyer touches Rover’s paw with his wing.

Rover, it’s easy for you to see that it’s crazy when it’s between bats and other animals. But can you see that it’s crazy also when its between cats and dogs? Rover looks into the sky as if he’s been struck by lightening.  38.
My goodness, you're right. It doesn’t matter if we’re different. What matters is ... is...
What’s in your hearts. Rover looks back at Flyer.
Well, I know what’s in mine.
I guess there’s only one thing left to find out then, isn’t there?
Yes, absolutely! Thank you, Flyer! Thank you! Rover sets of down the street at a full sprint. Flyer watches him go happily.
‘Atta boy. INT. JULIET’S BEDROOM Doc is helping Juliet slip out of her polar bear costume she begins to notice that Juliet seems very depressed abo something.
Are you all right, Juliet? You haven’t said a word since the party. But it is as if Juliet is in a dream.
I’m sorry. What did you say, Rover?
Rover!
I’m sorry, did I say Rover?
Yes, you did. I’ve been called a lot of things in my day, but Rover isn’t one of them. Juliet ... Doc lifts Juliet’s chin.
Have you been rubbing whiskers with with one of the canine persuasion?  39. Juliet hides her eyes from Doc, but she knows there’s no trying to hide the truth from her.

Yes, I have. I met him at the party. We talked. We danced. But in the end ... (starting to cry) Oh Rover, Rover, wherefore art thou Rover! Doc takes a tissue from the vanity table and dries Juliet eyes.
Oh Doc, you won’t tell anyone, will you?
Of course not. We love kittens got to stick together. Just don’t let Tyger find out. At that moment A LONELY HOWL is heard outside the house. Juliet crosses to the window and looks down into the stre
It’s Rover!
Rover?
Oh my goodness!
Hey, he’s kind of cute.
You think so?
Well, for a dog...
Oh, Doc, what am I going to do?
Go out and talk to him.
Talk to him? What do I say?
Say, “Hey ya big boy, why don’t you come up and see me some time?”
I can’t say that!  40.
Then just be yourself. You'll be fine. Juliet opens the window and slips out on the balcony. Rov clears his throat and begins to speak.
But soft! What light from over yonder comes and breaks my window.
What?
That’s not right. I mean what yonder broke my light ... I mean my window ...
Rover, what are you saying?
I’m saying ... He looks up at her suddenly full of confidence.
I’m saying that I love you.
What?
I love you, Juliet. And I want to know if you love me too. Because if you do, then all the differences between us will mean nothing.
Oh Rover, I do love you. Very much. Rover suddenly flies into a series of back flips. Juliet laughs delightedly.
Come to me, Rover.
Come to you?
Jump up here.
I can’t jump up there.
Why not?  41.
Because I can’t jump that high. I'ma dog, remember?
Oh. So what do we do?
You’re going to have to come down here.
But I can’t do that.
Why not?
Because I’ve never been out of the house before.
You've never seen Verona? The most beautiful town in the world?
No.
Then come with me Juliet, and I will show it to you, and you will have the most wonderful night of your life. Juliet looks at Doc questioningly.
Doc?
Just don’t do anything I wouldn’t do.
But there isn’t anything you wouldn’t do. Doc smiles mischievously.

Exactly. Taking one last look into her bedroom, Juliet turns and dashes off the balcony. She leaps high into the air and lands right beside Rover. After looking dreamily into his eyes, Juliet finally shrugs shyly.
Verona, remember?
Oh yes ... Verona. And what would you like to see first?  42.
All of it. I want to see all of it. And with that the happy couple darts off into the city, p in paw. Flyer, who has been observing the young lovers fr a tree limb, flaps behind them.

A moment later, Rover and Juliet are SWINGING AROUND LAMP POSTS and DANCING IN THE STREETS. Juliet is, of course, fascinated by everything she sees, but especially by the of light and the oranges and other round fruits she sees through a market's window. Overcome with chivalry, Rover sneaks in the back door of market and returns a minute later with a couple of nectar that he’s pawned.
Where to next?
(Pointing to the fruit) Throw it.
What?
Throw it! Rover FLINGS the nectarine down the street. Juliet points the direction it has gone. JULIET (cont'd) I want to go there!

Rover and Juliet have caught up with the rolling fruit. Laughing and giggling, they kick it on further ... straig down the sidewalk and into the opera house. Outside the front door, Rover and Juliet dodge the legs o people entering the opera house. Slowly a DEVILISH GRIN spreads across Juliet’s face and she bolts into the opera house after the nectarine. Rover is right behind her!
The nectarine is being inadvertently kicked around the fr lobby. Before Rover and Juliet can catch up to it though, is kicked down a back hallway toward a dressing room.
Rover and Juliet tear after the bouncing nectarine only t become accidentally entangled in TWO ELABORATE COSTUMES.  43.
The nectarine continues to roll just out of reach of Rove and Juliet who have now come to be wearing the elaborate costumes!

Finally the nectarine comes to rest ... downstage center! A second later Rover and Juliet catch up to it there. The the lights go down. A HUSH falls over the audience. The CONDUCTOR taps his baton and clears his throat. All e fall _on Rover and Juliet, who look at one another.
What are we supposed to do now?
Sing, I think.
Sing what?
(Whispering) Your first line is “Figaro.”
Figaro? Suddenly the orchestra springs to life. Beautiful music fills the chamber. But Rover and Juliet struggle to sing operatically.
Figaro! Figaro!
Figaro! Suddenly, two underwear clad opera singers appear onstage begin chasing Rover and Juliet around.

Finally making it back outside the opera house, Rover jum into a flowerbed and begins picking roses and daisies lef and right. Soon he has made a gigantic bouquet, which he presents proudly to Juliet. As Rover and Juliet come out the garden, a delightful smell wafts by and tempts their noses.
Following the smell down the street, they come to “Domino Bakery.” Peering in the front window, they see a young APPRENTICE taking loaves of bread from the oven.

Unable to resist the smell of the fresh-baked bread, Rove and Juliet sneak into the bakery and creep nearer and nea the bread. But then Rover accidentally swats a pepper shaker with hi tail, making the Apprentice sneeze. The just risen loaves bread fall as flat as pancakes. The baker, SENOR DOMINO, becomes incensed and swats the Apprentice with his hat. A chase around the bakery begins, where the TOMATO and MOZZARELLA, which the baker was eating for supper, end up being spread on the FLATTENED LOAVES OF BREAD. Just as Senor Domino has the Apprentice cornered, he smel the PIE SHAPED CREATION on top of the stove. Suddenly he has an idea and cuts the pie into TRIANGULAR PIECES. After smelling one curiously, he plops it in his mouth.
Hey, that’s pretty good! As Senor Domino chomps down another bite, the Apprentice flattens out a bread box, making the first pizza box.
Wait a second, I got it! We’1ll deliver!

We'll call it Domino's! In their joy of their new discovery, they don’t notice ho Rover creeps up to the stove ... and swipes the first piz in the history of the world! On the way out the door, Juliet snatches the Apprentice’s bottle of milk, too!
Rover and Juliet are riding in a gondola down the river, eating the pizza and drinking the milk and being serenade a quartet of string-playing crickets.
It would go great with a little pepperoni, wouldn’t you say?
I think I'd prefer anchovies. When they come to an arched bridge, Rover takes Juliet’s and they're off again.
Come on!  45.
Rover and Juliet continue their happy romp through town. Soon, they come to the Arena. Rover runs right through th front door.
What is this?
It’s the Arena!
Rover and Juliet scamper up to the emperor’s box and look the Roman ruins around them.

Can you imagine what it was like back then? Suddenly, magically, the Arena is transformed into its classical glory! TOGA-CLAD SPECTATORS are doing “the wave”. GLADIATORS prepare to fight EXOTIC BEASTS. A wreathed sports announc looking an awful lot like Marv Albert does the play by pl In an instant, a WOOLY MAMMOTH charges at a gladiator in center of the ring. The gladiator is ROVER! Rover, however is too enamored of Juliet and doesn’t noti the tusked beast bearing down on him. Juliet meows ...! Just in time! Rover leaps to the side, using a toga as a Matador uses a cape. Within seconds, Rover has brought th beast to the ground, and has wrapped its trunk around its feet like a cowboy ropes a calf. Juliet tosses roses to Rover, who picks them up with his teeth.
An instant later, Rover and Juliet are dashing for the hi It’s all Flyer can do to keep up with them.

Rover and Juliet sit side by side with all of Verona belo them. The sun is just coming up. They look deep into one another’s eyes ... Just as they begin to move closer to one another, Flyer c to the top of the hill and is hit by direct sunlight. Thi knocks his RADAR all out of whack and he promptly crashes into a CHICKEN COOP getting egg all over himself. Back on the top of the hill, meanwhile, all the other ani (except dogs and cats of course) have gathered around to Rover and Juliet move CLOSER and CLOSER.  46. When the young lovers kiss, it is like all of Italy sighs with them. Just seconds later, Flyer gets to the scene.

Darn, I missed the best part. Rover and Juliet look at him and then back at one another When they kiss again, Flyer literally shivers with happin Then they turn, paw in paw, and watch the sunlight contin to spread over Verona.
Verona still sleeps as Rover and Juliet return home from their adventure. When they reach The Cat-Pulets’ villa, t two young lovers stop at its gates and look at each other longingly.
Well ... Here we are.
(Sighing) Home.
Last night was amazing.
I‘1l never forget it as long as I live.
I won’t either. Juliet starts under the gate.
I just wish ...
Yeah?
I just wish we could do this every night.
And every day, too.
But if our families ever found out ...
We'd never get to see each other again. The lovers tremble merely at the thought.  47.
This feud is so dumb! I mean, cats and dogs aren't so different.
We both walk on four legs ...
We both have tails ...
We both fall in love.
(Smiling) Yeah ... We both do, don’t we.
You know, maybe there is a way we can be together and stop our two families from fighting.
But how?
Come with me. To the cathedral!
A glorious renaissance church in the heart of Verona. THE CAMERA TRACKS UP the facade of the cathedral right into i bell tower.
Flyer hangs upside down from the rafters, reading ‘How to Friends and Influence Animals.’ Rover and Juliet stand be
(Throwing down his book) You want me to WHAT?
I want you to marry us.
Don’t you think you’re moving just a little fast?
It’s the only way, Flyer. Romeo told me that he and the girl Juliet were going to be married in the church ...
They were. The Friar performed the ceremony. It was a small but lovely affair.  48.
Romeo also said that getting married would help end the feud between their two families.

I gotta hand it to the boy, he’s sharp. Rover and Juliet look up at Flyer, knowingly. FLYER (cont'd) Oh ... I get it. You think you two could do the same for cats and dogs. The lovers smile and nod. FLYER (cont'd) Maybe, but I’m not a friar. I’m just a bat who lives in the belfry. That’s what bats do.
Please, Flyer. If it weren’t for you, Juliet and I wouldn’t even be together. All you have to do is say a few words. Nothing fancy.
I don’t know ... Juliet notices the title of Flyer’s book and gets an idea
Come on, Rover. Let’s go home. He’s just an old, scary-looking bat.
Now wait a second, young lady.

It’s not like he wants to help end the feud between cats and dogs. I mean then everybody would like him. Nobody would be afraid of him anymore. Juliet’s reverse-psychology works. Flyer swoops down from the ceiling and stops them.
I guess I could say a few words. I have watched enough weddings in my day. Rover and Juliet smile.
Come. Gather close. Flyer hovers in front of the couple.  49.
Do you, Rover, take Juliet to be your wife?
You bet I do!
And do you, Juliet, take Rover to be your husband?
Yes. I do.
Then by the power you have vested in me, I now pronounce you ... cat and dog. You may kiss the kitty. They kiss. As if on cue, the CHURCH BELLS begin to ring!
Rover and Juliet climb out the window and onto the street Suddenly, RICE begins to fall on their heads. They both l up and find Flyer clutching a bag.
What’s a wedding without rice? They smile and wave. Rover notices the people on the stre
Wow, I better get you home.
No, Rover. We better split up. At least until we tell our families the news.
Then we can be together whenever we want.
I can’t wait!
I’1l meet you back at your house with the rest of The Mongrels. I think we should tell everyone together.
I agree. Farewell, Rover. Parting is such sweet sorrow.
Hey, that’s kinda nice ... They sneak a final kiss and Juliet dashes off. Rover is l with a huge smile on his face.  50.
Once again, the market place is bustling with people. INT. UNDER THE WATCHMAKER’S KIOSK Benny, Mercury and Big Daddy wait impatiently. Benny snatches one of the watchmaker’s watches and checks the t
Where do you think Rover is?
Don’t ask me. But he was acting pretty strange at the party last night.
Speaking of The Cat-Pulet’s party, I heard what you boys did.
You should have seen it, Big Daddy. It was great!
No, Benny, it was stupid. Now all of the other animals probably hate us as much as the cats do. You pups need to pick your fights more carefully.
But Big Daddy, those cats - Big Daddy rises over Mercury.
Sorry, Big Daddy. We’1l be more careful. I promise. Rover finally arrives.
And where have you been? You’re late.
Big Daddy waits for an explanation.
Overslept?
(Whispering) Good answer.
Because of your failure to pull off the butcher heist, Rover, The Mongrels went (MORE )
BIG DADDY (cont'd) hungry. That’s not going to happen again ... (Looming over Rover) Is_it?
No, Big Daddy.
Today I’m sending you three on a mission even the dumbest dogs could do.
Tyger and his henchcats watch as The Mongrels sneak acros the marketplace. Tyger wears a gold WHISTLE around his ne
Well if it isn’t our little friends the skunks ...
Something is smelly in The State of Denmark.
We’re in Verona, you idiot!
Et tu, Ty-gre? Tyger WHACKS them both across the head.
SHUT UP! I have a plan to insure every mongrel in Verona thinks twice before messing with The Cat-Pulets again.
The dogs pick through the scraps. Mercury finds a T-Bone.
Look at this beauty!
I better find one, too. I need to be on Big Daddy's good side today.
What’s so special about today?
I have something important to tell the family.
Oh yeah? So tell us.  52.
Well ... Rover decides if he wants to spill the beans.
Yes. Tell us, Rover. The dogs look up and find the cats right behind them.
Tell us all what’s so important.
So I see you brought your goons this time.
Goons?
He is a dog of most infinite jest. Tyger hisses at Shake and Speare. Then he approaches Mercury.
I have some unfinished business with you Mongrels. A little payback for crashing our party. Rover gets between Tyger and Mercury.
Listen, we’re all very sorry about what we did, Tyger.
What are you doing, Rover? These fluffballs don’t deserve an apology. They deserve a nice bite on the behind.
No, Mercury. Fighting isn’t the answer.
Oh yeah? Then what is? Everyone looks at Rover.
Love. The cats and dogs break out in hysterics.
This little doggie’s nuts! Benny steps forward and joins Rover.  53.
Maybe Rover's right.
Benny!
I don’t like fighting, Merc’. It’s really stupid. And for me, that’s saying a lot.
Looks like The Mongrels aren’t so tough after all. Mercury sticks his face up to Tyger’s.
Just try me, Pussy.
Remember what Big Daddy said, Merc’. We have to choose our fights more carefully.
He's right, Merc’. Just take the bone and walk away.
What’s it going to be? Are you a dog ... or a chicken? Mercury is ready to attack, but surprisingly, he steps ba
You ain’t worth it, Tyger. Mercury turns around and starts to walk away when suddenl TYGER POUNCES ON HIM, running his razor sharp claws down Mercury’s back. He draws blood.

Why you ...! The henchcats grab Rover and Benny. Tyger has Mercury on back while he continues to claw him. Rover can’t stand to watch his friend being hurt. With al of his might, he shoves the henchcats to the ground and j on top of Tyger, pulling him off of Mercury. Rover gets Tyger pinned down. He opens his jaws, ready to bite the vicious cat. ROVER (cont'd) I don’t want to have to bite you, Tyger!

Believe me, you’re not going to get the chance!  54. Tyger BLOWS on his gold whistle. At first, Rover doesn’t understand why. Then the sound of a horse approaching fas is heard. Rover looks up and sees ... ..- THE DOG CATCHER, his silver net in the air. Before Ro can run away, the net swoops down and scoops him up. The Catcher holds Rover to his face.
Gotcha, Mongrel! I told you I would. Fortunately, someone left me this anonymous note ... Rover sees the note. Written sloppily, it reads, ‘IF YOU

head_text.subj: WANT TO FIND THE MONGRELS IN THE PIAZZA, JUST LISTEN FOR

text: WHISTLE.’ Rover looks down at Tyger grinning. He holds up his paws. It is covered in BLACK INK. The gold whistle is still in mouth. The Dog Catcher gallops off with Rover. Benny and Mercury can only watch helplessly as their friend is take away.

The place is jam-packed with stray dogs. When The Dog Cat attempts to shove Rover into one of the already crowded cages, the frightened pup pops right out. The Dog Catcher grabs Rover by a tuft of fur and holds him up to his face

Well, it looks like it’s your lucky day, poochy. No room at the pound. The Dog Catcher brings Rover close. DOG CATCHER (cont’d) Now what shall I do with you, hmm? I hear in some countries, little doggies are a delicacy. Rover shivers in terror. DOG CATCHER (cont’d) No. You're too small to cook. I have a better idea.
The Mongrels gather around Mama Mongrel as she licks Mercury’s wounds.
What the Cat-Pulets did today is an act of war! From this day forth, let no feline feel safe in Verona. The Mongrels are fighting back!  55.
The Cat-Pulets gather in the living room. Lady Cat-Pulet licks Tyger’s wounds.
What the Mongrels did today is an act of war! From this day forth, let no canine feel safe in Verona.
Don’t worry, father. The Dog Catcher took care of the Mongrel that attacked me.
(Concerned) What was the name of the dog?
Rover. How cliché. Juliet is in shock. She turns to Doc.
(Whispering) I can’t believe Rover would do something like that.

Our mortal enemy has always been the dog. And now you can see why. It’s time The Cat-Pulets fought back! The Cat-Pulets meow in agreement, then follow Lord Cat-Pu out of the room. As Juliet is leaving, she overhears Tyge and his henchcats.
It was pretty clever how I made it look like Rover attacked me just as the dog catcher came by. Tyger laughs devilishly. Juliet now knows the truth.
Juliet runs in and grabs Doc.
Doc, Tyger set Rover up! My husband is innocent! Go to the pound and tell Rover I know the truth and that I still love him. I just hope he’s all right ...
The Dog Catcher rides just outside the city and drops Rov on a dirt road.  56.
Hit the road, mutt. You’re banished! And if I ever see your grubby little face again, you'll be meat for my meatballs.
Rover starts down the road. The Dog Catcher rides back in the city. The gates slam shut behind him. Rover stops and turns around.
I’m not going anywhere without seeing Juliet one last time ...
A furious scratching is heard beneath the earth. After a moment Rover pokes his head out. He’s burrowed his way un the wall and comes out completely covered in mud. He’s ev got dirt in his mouth.

Patooie! Yeeech! He looks up at the high wall towering above him. ROVER (cont'd) Man, I need to learn to jump. Shaking himself off as best he can, Rover starts off for Cat-Pulets’, but no sooner is he on the road than he sees BLACK HORSE APPROACHING AT A THUNDERING PACE. ROVER (cont'd) Oh no! The Dog-Catcher! Rover leaps from the road and buries himself in a pile of leaves, only to discover that the horse is being ridden b cute little boy. Getting up cautiously, Rover slinks from lamp post to lamp post completely covered in leaves. It looks as though he’s been tarred and feathered.

Nearing the piazza, Rover turns a corner and heads down a street leading to the Cat-Pulets’. Again, we hear a horse approaching. This time it is the Dog Catcher, but Rover h hidden himself in the shadows. The Dog Catcher is more menacing than ever, now wielding whip and striking at any animal in the street.
Yee-ah! Yee-ah! The Rats, who are having supper in the alley, are nearly lashed by the whip. After the Dog Catcher is gone, they return to their meal. Rover listens in.  57.
Hey, what’s up with Igor?
Ah, he’s mad about pulling a double shift. Ever since that dumb mutt started the riot in the square.
You mean Rover?

That's his name. You should have heard the Cat-Pulets cursing him when I was up there stealing this cheese. Every one of them! That mutt better not go anywhere near that place, let me tell you. (Gesturing to his plate) Rougefort?
Why thank you. Rover walks away from the rats dejected. Finding a puddle water, he looks at his reflection.

(To himself) Every one of the Cat-Pulets! Do you think ... Juliet could hate me too? Rover looks up at the Cat-Pulets’ house and ponders for a second. Then he turns and runs down the street in the opposite direction.
Doc is walking down the street muttering to herself.
Can you imagine? A cat on the way to the pound? Just think what this will do to my reputation? When she turns the corner, Doc sees Rover sprinting down street still partially covered in leaves.
(To herself) Rover?! Where you off to in such a hurry? Doc looks down a hill and can see that Rover is heading straight for the cathedral. Sighing, she sets off after h
From the pound to the church. Talk about out of your element!  58.
Flyer stands before a mirror combing his hair with dippit hair gel.
Maybe if I part it on the side, nobody will think I’m so... Suddenly, Rover enters the church window and leaps into t belfry.
(Panting) Flyer? Where are you Flyer? Flyer hides his hair gel and tries to flatten down his ha
I’m right here. What’s wrong?
I’ve been vanished!
Vanished? What do you mean?
Like from Verona.
Oh you mean “banished”.
Exactly.
Why?
Because I got in a fight with Tyger, only it wasn’t my fault, but then the dog catcher came, and he thought it was my fault, but it wasn’t, I swear. I swear!
Rover, you shouldn’t swear in church -
And now all the Cat-pulets hate me, even Juliet! What am I going to do, Flyer? What am I ever going to do? Rover collapses in tears on the floor of the belfry. Flye looks down on him with irritation.
Come on, get up!  59.
I can’t. Can’t you see? My life is over. Oh, woe is me! Flyer decides to try a little reverse psychology.
Why you’re nothing but a hound dog, crying all the time. Rover looks up at Flyer, slightly indignant.
A hound dog?
There’s always hope, Rover. No matter how bleak things look. You just got to get up and keep trying.
But what hope can there be for me now? At that instant Doc appears at the window above Rover and Flyer. She postures herself like a nightclub performer fr the 1940's.
Hey ya big boys. Why you look so glum?
Doc! Rover leaps to his feet and rushes to the stairs below Do As he starts to scramble up, Doc yells sharply.
Rover, stay where you are! Rover freezes and looks up at Doc confused.
You’re ruining my big entrance. And with that, Doc saunters down the steps with her tail wrapped about her shoulders like a mink stole.
I bring word from my lady.
What oh what, tell me please! Does she hate me? Does she never want to see me again? Tell me, please, I have to know.
Tell me something, do all dogs drool like that?  60. It’s all Rover can do to keep from ringing Doc’s neck.

head_text.subj: TELL ME WHAT YOU KNOW ABOUT JULIET

text: Ah quit your yelping. She loves you still.
(ecstatic) She does?
And she knows Tyger had you set up.
She does?
And she wants to see you as soon she can.
She does?
She does. Rover scrambles toward the open window.
Then I’m going now!
Just a second! Rover pauses at the window.
What?
You aren’t going to go looking like that are you? For a golden retriever you’re looking a little tarnished.

Don’t you worry, Doc. Don’t you worry. Rover heads out of the belfry completely excited. EXT. BENEATH JULIET THE GIRL’S BALCONY - NIGHT Rover approaches the balcony thoroughly cleaned. He seems be on top of the world, until he remembers how high the balcony is. Seeing no other choice, he takes a few steps back and cha  61. toward the balcony. A few feet from the wall he makes a tremendous leap ... but only makes it about half way up a crashes back down to the ground.

Now what am I going to do? Truly starting to become dejected, Rover’s spirits change when he sees ROMEO APPROACH CARRYING A LADDER. Romeo places the ladder against the balcony and begins to up but then thinks of something and goes back down. Then begins to look for something in the garden. Rover takes advantage of the opportunity and scampers rig up the ladder. He is just about to steal into Juliet’s chamber when he turns and discovers Romeo picking flowers Juliet the Girl in the garden. Feeling like he needs to do the same for his Juliet, Rove goes back down the ladder. Down in the garden, Romeo sees Rover.

Oh loyal pooch. Have you a fair maiden of your own? Perchance a beagle? A collie? And must you stake your very life just to set eyes upon her? I think not. How much simpler it would be to be a lowly dog! Romeo scratches Rover behind the ears and heads back to t ladder with his bouquet. Once Romeo has gotten off the to Rover scrambles up behind him. Just as both Romeo and Rover are about to enter their respective entrances on the balcony, they are simultaneou overcome with a teenager’s sense of insecurity. Completely unaware that the other is doing the same thing the same time, both the dog and the boy look at their reflections in the window and fix their hair. Then they flex their biceps and blow into their hand/paw check for bad breath. Finally convinced that all is in order, the lovers puff up their chests and make their dashingly romantic entrances. INT. JULIET THE GIRL’S BEDROOM Both Juliet and Juliet the Girl are primping themselves a the door to the balcony opens. The male lovers swagger in Juliet sees Rover ... Juliet the Girl sees Romeo ... Both sets of lovers jump into each other’s arms! INT. JULIET THE GIRL’S BEDROOM - DAYBREAK Romeo and Juliet the Girl lay in one another’s arms on th love seat. Meanwhile, underneath the bed, Rover and Julie do exactly the same thing.  62. After a moment, we hear A BIRD CALL. ROVER AND JULIET’S POV Romeo’s legs come off the bed and move to the window. A moment later we hear the CURTAINS TORN OPEN and the room fills with light.
Rover looks at Juliet, panicked at how late it’s gotten. Pecking her on the cheek he gets up to go. Juliet grabs h desperately just as ...
Wilt thou be gone? It is not yet day. Juliet squeezes Rover so tightly he begins to turn blue! It's like she’s put a VICE around his neck ...
I must be gone and live ... Finally he breaks through Juliet’s clutches and catapults across the room, knocking over an expensive lamp!

«+. or stay and die. ABOVE ... Romeo and Juliet the Girl are so enamored of one another they haven’t noticed the lamp crash to the ground. BELOW ... Juliet has pounced on Rover again. He points out the wind desperately to the rising sun ...
‘Tis the morn. Look love ... Juliet shakes her head and closes her eyes, childishly refusing to acknowledge the morning.
Yond light is not day-light. Suddenly, Juliet radically shifts tactics, lifting up the blanket and casting a FLIRTATIOUS LOOK Rover's way.
Therefore stay yet, - thou need’st not to be gone. This is too much for Rover to resist and he dives under t covers to be with Juliet.  63.
Let me be put to death! Juliet wills it so. It is not day. Suddenly Juliet is FRANTIC to get Rover out of the bedroo Only now Rover clings to Juliet!

It is, it is, - hie hence be gone, away! She pushes Rover toward the window RIPPING up the bedshee KNOCKING over the vanity table, and SMASHING the chest of drawers. In addition, the canopy from the bed has gotten caught on
chandelier ... Romeo and Juliet The Girl, meanwhile, still have ABSOLUTE NO IDEA the room is being literally DEMOLISHED!
--. O, now be gone; more light and light it grows. The Nurse and Doc enter simultaneously. Doc stares at the destruction around her.
Your lady mother is coming to your chamber: The day is broke;
(to herself) So’s the lamp ...

Be wary! Look about! The chandelier crashes to the ground! ... narrowly missin all of the lovers, who are STILL oblivious to the room be destroyed. They can only look deeply into one another’s eyes ... Finally, dramatically, Juliet the Girl opens the window.
Then window, let day in, and let life out.

Farewell, farewell! One kiss and I’1l descend. Both pairs of lovers kiss simultaneously. Then Rover and Romeo head out the window and disappear into the street. Juliet and Juliet the Girl watch them go sadly. Finally, Juliet the Girl notices that Juliet is there.  64.

Oh Kitty Juliet, alack the day! Have you a dashing prince far hence? Some Siamese cat? Some Noble Persian? It must be so much simpler to be a cat. Both crying now, Juliet and Juliet the girl comfort one another.
Rover has breakfast with the pigs at their trough.
I don’t know how you fellas eat this slop.
You get used to it.
Those scraps in the piazza are looking pretty good now. Sure wish I was back home ... (Sighs) ++. with Juliet. The pigs look at Rover sympathetically for a moment, then return to their slop.
Rover walks inside and finds the barn empty. Confused, he BARKS.

Romeo? Where are ya, Romeo? Rover then finds Romeo’s red feathered cap. His human fri is gone. INT. JULIET’S ROOM Juliet curls up by the window, looking out at the falling rain. She is still quite sad. Doc saunters in.
Are you planing on being miserable forever?
I miss him, Doc. I miss him more and more each day. And to make matters worse, Juliet’s gone too. I haven’t seen her for days.  65.
You know how humans get when they’re in love. They can’t think about anything else.
I’m starting to understand why.
You gotta snap out of this, kid. Your folks are real worried about you. I heard they’re even going to ...
They're going to what, Doc?
They're going to ask ... Just then, Lord and Lady Cat-Pulet enter, followed by Vie the snobby Viennese cat from the party.
-.. Vienna to marry you. Vienna bows before Juliet and kisses her paw.
Juliet, how purr-fect you look! Alarmed, Juliet looks at Doc.
Oh no ...!
Rover lies alone in the fields and HOWLS at the moon.
First I lose my girl, then I lose my best friend. Could things get any worse? As if one cue, it begins to rain. Rover is soaked.
They could ... He bows his head and begins to cry.
Are you okay? Rover looks up and finds an adorable FEMALE, GOLDEN RETRI PUPPY standing by the farmer’s house.
Well, to be honest ... not really.  66.
Why don’t you come inside? The farmer just put out some food. Rover’s tempted, but not sure.
(Smiling) Come on. I won’t bite. Rover walks out of the fields and follows the cute puppy inside.
Flyer is experimenting with different breath sprays when Juliet leaps into the the belfry.
Flyer!
What?
You’re never going to believe what's happened!
What?
My parents want me to get married with Vienna.
Well did you try to talk them out of it?
Of course I did. But they wouldn’t hear it. I can’t stand it how they treat me like I’m some kind of kitten! Flyer, what am I going to do?
I don’t know. Flyer thinks for a moment. Then he shrugs his shoulders.
Well, when in doubt ... Flyer flies down to the sanctuary below. Juliet leaps dow after him.
When in doubt what?  67. Flyer comes across a vial, which contains a potion and si on the Friar’s lectern.
When in doubt, do what people do.
Do what people do? What did they do?
Well, believe it or not, this same situation is happening between Romeo and Juliet.
No!
Can you imagine? What are the chances? And so when your Juliet came here just a little while ago, Friar Laurence gave her a potion like this which will make it seem like she has died -
Died!
Don’t be afraid. It will only seem that she has died. Really. Flyer picks up a piece of chalk and begins scrawling on a piece of slate like a coach diagramming a play.
She’1ll just be sleeping. So then she won’t have to marry Paris. Because then her parents will think she’s dead, see? And who’d want to marry a dead person anyway, right? Is this making any sense?
I’m not sure ...

Well, let me see if I got this straight. What’s really going to be happening is that Juliet’s just going to be sleeping The chalk figures that Flyer has drawn come to life and t to act out the elaborate plan. But they become as confuse as Juliet is becoming.
--. and in forty two hours she’1l wake up good as new, and then Romeo will be there  68.
How?
Yeah, how?

I don’t know how! Somehow, all right? And they’1ll go run off together and make a new life together ... in Mantua or somewhere. You got it? The Chalk Figures shake their heads vehemently. Juliet tu to Flyer tentatively.
And you're saying this same plan would work for me and Rover?
That’s exactly what I’m saying.
I don’t know ...
What do you mean, you don’t know?
Well, it’s just it sounds so... dangerous. And so complicated. It just seems like there’s a lot of things that could go wrong.
Like what?
I don’t know. It just doesn’t sound wise
But Friar Laurence said -
Well who cares what Friar Laurence said -
I do.
Why?
Because he’s human, that’s why! And everybody knows that humans are smarter than animals. And if they’ve made this plan ... well, it must be better than any (MORE )
FLYER (cont'd) plan we could come up with. Don’t you think?
I guess so. Neither one of them seem too convinced of the wisdom of t plan, but Flyer puts the potion in front of Juliet anyway

Now take this vial and get yourself back to your house and do exactly as I have said. You hear? Flyer opens his wings and starts flying toward the open window. FLYER (cont'd) I will fly now to Mantua to tell Rover of our plan! Juliet looks at the vial on the lectern. Finally she pick it up and turns to go. The Chalk Figures shake their head in disapproval.
You'll be sorry ...
Flyer flaps along panting rapidly. The two Doves fly near almost mocking how slowly the little bat struggles throug the air.

I wish I was a bird. (Almost completely out of breath) I wish I was a bird. Suddenly, Flyer sees something below that literally stops in mid-air. FLYER (cont'd) Oh no! As Flyer zooms down to the ground, he becomes even more upset. FLYER (cont'd) No! Say it isn’t so! Flyer lands finally on the steps of a large marble struct called “The Monument of the Lovers”. There beside him lay the MOTIONLESS BODIES OF ROMEO AND JULIET THE GIRL. They embrace each other gently and seem almost to be sleeping. But the vial that lies beside Romeo’s outstretched hand a the knife beside Juliet the Girl let Flyer know that thes lovers will never wake up again.  70. The Doves look down on the scene from above. FLYER (cont'd) Did Romeo find Juliet sleeping and think --.? And so then he took this poison --.? And she ... waking up to find him dead ... did she ... take the knife and

Flyer cries out loud. FLYER (cont'd) Oh how did this happen? How can this be? Flyer covers his head with his wings and sobs. The Doves look on from above. For the first time they begin to real that Flyer is more than just a scary little bat. Just as they start to come closer, a terrible realization spreads across Flyer’s face. FLYER (cont'd) But wait! If this happened to Romeo and Juliet, then the same thing could happen to ... He turns and looks back toward Verona. FLYER (cont'd) I’ve got to get back to Juliet and tell her not to take that potion! Setting off toward Verona, Flyer comes over a hill and is by sunlight. Once again his radar malfunctions and he spi out of control to the ground. FLYER (cont'd) Oh, how can it get any worse than this? The Doves look at one another, truly worried. INT. JULIET THE GIRL’S BEDROOM Juliet sits on Juliet the Girl’s bed considering Flyer’s POTION. The Chalk Figures hover nearby.
Don’t do it! You know it doesn’t make sense - But she starts to drink it anyway. As she tips the vial higher, she sees herself in the mirror. Suddenly she stop drinking and looks herself in the eye.

Juliet, what are you doing? Of course this doesn’t make sense. But the potion starts to take effect. Just as she falls unconscious she sets the vials on the floor.  71. We see now, she has only drank HALF OF THE POTION.

location: NEAR THE MONUMENT OF THE LOVERS

text: Flyer is trying to do anything he can to see in the light he can fly off to Verona again. He even tries flying with seeing-eye-stick, only to come crashing down to the earth He ends up wrapped in thick vines, nearly unable to move all.

Oh, it’s no good. I’11 never be able to see in the light! Flyer’s head droops as he realizes there’s no hope. But not too far away, the Doves look down, touched by Fly determination to help Rover and Juliet. Finally they must the courage to fly down to him. A moment later they have begun to peel away the vines. FLYER (cont'd) Hey! Hey! What are you doing? Get away from me!
Shhh. Squinting to make out who it is, Flyer begins to understa

What? Are you here ... to help me? The Doves nod. FLYER (cont'd) Me? Scary Flyer? His answer is to be lifted gently into the air. The Doves one on each of Flyer’s wing, take him higher and higher a head off toward Verona. INT. JULIET THE GIRL’S BEDROOM Lady and Lord Cat-pulet and Doc come into the room. Doc i carrying a beautiful white wedding dress. Juliet lies motionless on Juliet The Girl’s pillow.
Juliet? Look, darlin’. Look what I made of the sheets you tore up. (Observing her more closely) Juliet?
Juliet, wake up!
What’s wrong with her?  72.
I don’t know.

Is she ...? Is she ...? As Lady Cat-Pulet looks closer and closer at her daughter she begins to realize that something is truly wrong. EXT. JULIET’S BALCONY - LATER Doc lies on the stone wall, weeping. The rats, on their w out of the sewer, feel her tear drops land on their tiny heads. They look up.
What’s with the waterworks, Doc?
(Sobbing) My best friend is dead.
Juliet? Doc sobs and nods ‘yes.’
That’s terrible.
She was so young ...
So beautiful ...
And that’s saying a lot coming from a couple of rats.
Is there anything we can do?
You can tell all the animals. Tell them Juliet will be buried in the cat-a-combs at sunset.
We won’t let you down, Doc!
The rats climb through holes in the walls of villas throughout Verona to tell domestic animals the news.  73.
The rats scurry through the square to tell all of the cit stray animals the news.
The rats go from cage to cage. The elephant uses his trun to wipe the tears from his eyes.
The rats peer through a window in the bell tower, but Fly is gone. Instead, the rats tell the pigeons perched atop cathedral. The pigeons, saddened, fly off.
Now all of Italy will know of Juliet’s passing ...
As Rover tries to leave the farmer’s house, he is surroun by A LARGE FAMILY of golden retrievers.
My family really likes you, Rover. The dogs lick and jump all over him.
You think? The Female Puppy snuggles up to Rover.
They think we make a great couple.
(Surprised) A couple? All we did was share a can of Alpo. Just then, the pigs saunter by on their way to the trough
Such a pretty cat gone before her time.
It’s rumored she died of a broken heart.
Seems to be happening a lot in Verona these days. Rover's curiosity is piqued.  74.
Excuse me, Pigs. Who are you talking about?
Haven’t you heard? Juliet Cat-Pulet is dead.
(Shocked) What?!
Did you know her ...?
Know her? She was my wife.
Your WIFE?!
Which way back to Verona? The pigs point.
Farewell, farm animals. I must see my sweet Juliet one last time! Rover runs down the dirt road. The female puppy turns to mother.
Why are all the cute dogs married?
As the Doves and Flyer approach the city walls, the Doves the Pigeons from the cathedral flying sadly back toward t They decide to fly up to them to find out what’s wrong.

Rover runs up to the entrance to the catacombs, completel out of breath. Because all his thoughts are on finding Juliet as quickly as possible, he doesn’t notice that Sha and Speare are keeping watch from across the street.
Zounds! Forsooth, wasn’t that the scoundrel Rover?
Perhaps we should exeunt stage left.
To Lord Tyger’s?  75.
Exactamundo! As Rover enters the catacombs, Shake and Speare laugh menacingly and head out to find Tyger.
The catacombs are a dark and somber place. The tunnels go lower and lower, lit by spooky torches. Frightening tombstones and artifacts fill the entire place. Rover loo around, unsure which way to go.
Mercury and Benny are moping beside the river when a huge mass of angry cats, led by Shake and Speare and Tyger run over the bridge near them. Mercury swats Benny with his tail.
Come on!
What do you think they’re up to?
I don’t know. But it can’t be anything good. Mercury and Benny head after the cat, whistling to other strays to come with them.
Rover is deeper in the catacombs choosing between two different passageways. It’s even spookier down here. It seems like a ghost could pop out at any moment.
